Linguistic analysis: The expert may have analyzed the language used in the claim to determine its authenticity. This could involve examining the grammar, syntax, and vocabulary to assess if it aligns with the typical patterns of speech.
Statistical data: The expert might have compared the claim of an unemployment rate of 18 to 20 percent with official statistical data or other reliable sources. They may have checked if there is any evidence to support or contradict the claim.
Contextual information: The expert could have looked into the broader context surrounding the claim, such as the source of the statement, the speaker's credibility, and any relevant historical or political factors. This could help in assessing the likelihood of the claim being authentic.
Cross: referencing with experts: The expert may have consulted other subject-matter experts or professionals in the field of economics or unemployment to validate or challenge the claim. This can provide additional perspectives and insights to support or question the authenticity of the statement.
